diagnosis.score_summary: No valid input data was detected (WWW provided as file reference, PDP as null). This is a GENERATED DEMO REPORT illustrating the engine's capability using the 'Cool vs. Cheap' scenario. The analysis below simulates a brand with a schizophrenic split between Luxury (WWW) and Commodity (PDP).

truth_1.headline: Cool vs. Cheap
truth_1.gap_description: The WWW signals 'Premium' to justify price. The PDP signals 'Basic' to drive volume. You are trying to be a luxury object on your site and a bargain bin item on Amazon.
truth_1.why_matters: Consumers check both channels. Seeing two different brands makes them doubt the value of the 'Cool' and the quality of the 'Cheap.'
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are stuck in the 'Uncanny Valley' of branding—too expensive to be a commodity, too cheap to be luxury. You must either strip the 'Value' signaling from Amazon to save the high-end dream (Option A), or rewrite the website to 'Masstige' and own the volume game (Option B). You cannot charge a premium price for a commodity soul.

truth_2.headline: The Grid Killed The Flow
truth_2.gap_description: WWW relies on 'Entropy' (swirls, motion). PDP relies on 'Grid' (static boxes). You are selling a liquid experience on one channel and solid geometry on the other.
truth_2.why_matters: Inconsistency in visual physics breaks the sensory promise. The user doesn't know if the product is 'Whipped' (WWW) or just 'Lotion' (PDP).
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are trying to sell a liquid sensation, but the Amazon platform is forcing you into a rigid spreadsheet. The compromise looks messy. You must either fight the platform with expensive PNG overlays to force the flow (Option A), or surrender to the grid and update your website to match the structured reality (Option B).

truth_3.headline: Artist vs. Dictator
truth_3.gap_description: Your website positions the brand as an artistic Creator, inviting the user in. Your Amazon listing positions it as a Ruler, demanding compliance.
truth_3.why_matters: The 'Creator' archetype implies premium discovery. The 'Ruler' implies standard utility. The mismatch confuses the customer's role in the relationship.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: The website invites collaboration; the marketplace demands submission. You must decide if you are a platform for creativity (Option A) or the standard-bearer of authority (Option B). You cannot be both the rebel and the police.

truth_4.headline: The Class Clown Problem
truth_4.gap_description: WWW caps Humor at 3/5. PDP pushes Humor to 4/5. You are getting laughs on Amazon, but you are creating a different personality than your home base.
truth_4.why_matters: A joke is only funny until it isn't. This drift suggests the Amazon team is improvising without the Brand team's playbook.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your Amazon team is getting laughs, but they are writing checks the Brand Strategy can't cash. You face a definitive choice: either muzzle the copywriter (Option A) to preserve your premium aura, or update the global voice to 'Cheeky' (Option B) and accept that you will alienate the serious buyer.

truth_5.headline: The Brand Home is Boring
truth_5.gap_description: WWW aims for 'Confidence' but plays it safe. PDP delivers 'Confidence' with higher intensity and is likely converting better because of it.
truth_5.why_matters: Your own website is the conservative bottleneck. The Amazon listing proves the audience is ready for more heat.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your website is whispering while your Amazon listing is screaming—and the scream is converting. You are at a crossroads: either force the Amazon listing back into the 'Safe' box to reduce risk (Option A), or codify the bolder intensity globally because the market has evolved (Option B).

marker_1.so_what: WWW sells a dream while PDP sells a tool. This disconnect ensures the dream feels fake and the tool feels overpriced.

marker_2.so_what: WWW wants to 'Elevate the World'; PDP wants to 'Make it Affordable'. These are opposing economic models.

marker_3.so_what: WWW preaches sustainability as a religion; PDP mentions it as a footnote. The values feel performative on the main site.

marker_4.so_what: The most dangerous gap. WWW is positioned as 'Premium Lifestyle' while PDP is 'Commodity Basic'. Price erosion is inevitable.

marker_5.so_what: WWW is 'Exclusive'; PDP is 'Friendly'. The brand feels bipolar—snobby at home, desperate on the street.

marker_6.so_what: WWW uses 'Creator' to signal innovation. PDP uses 'Ruler' to signal dominance. The customer sees arrogance, not art.

marker_7.so_what: The voice is the only consistent thread. Ironically, this consistent 'Hype' voice makes the visual disconnect even more jarring.

marker_8.so_what: WWW uses entropy/flow to signal luxury. PDP uses a rigid grid. The product looks like a different SKU on Amazon.

marker_9.so_what: WWW speaks in poetry; PDP speaks in bullet points. The poetry feels like fluff when compared to the hard facts on Amazon.

marker_10.so_what: Both channels attempt the same story, but PDP rushes the ending to get to the sale, losing the emotional arc.

marker_11.so_what: WWW highlights 'Craftsmanship' while PDP highlights 'Quantity'. You are training the customer to look for the cheapest option.

marker_12.so_what: The core technology claim is consistent, providing a necessary anchor amidst the other contradictions.

marker_13.so_what: Both channels focus on the product, but WWW allows for more lifestyle context. Acceptable variation.

marker_14.so_what: The technical promises are identical across channels. This is the only solid ground the customer stands on.

marker_15.so_what: Both channels promise 'Confidence', but PDP executes it with bolder claims, suggesting an Untapped Strength.

marker_16.so_what: WWW signals status; PDP signals rationality. You are canceling out your own brand equity.

marker_17.so_what: Consistent promise of community, though PDP emphasizes the size of the tribe rather than the quality.
